awd_titl_txt: CAS: A Rethinking of Borrowing Hydrogen: from Ligand Design to New Reactions and Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry, Keying Ding of Middle Tennessee State University will study catalytic reactions that result in the formation of carbon–carbon or carbon–heteroatom bonds. These reactions will be mediated by new earth-abundant metal catalytic systems that utilize the “borrowing hydrogen (BH)” pathway. This BH pathway is environmentally friendly and atom- and process-efficient in producing value-added chemicals while producing water as the sole byproduct.  Structure-reactivity correlations will be studied in an effort to glean critical information on how these catalysts facilitate this chemistry at the molecular level. The results will be used to direct catalyst development toward new and challenging reactions. This project will offer research experiences for students at the interface of synthetic inorganic chemistry, organic chemistry, and catalysis. The educational activities include efforts to enhance the participation of undergraduate students from underserved groups and low-income or first-generation families, participation in a summer research camp, and the integration of the funded research into teaching laboratories. The broader impacts of the research and educational activities will assist in the creation of a more diverse and educated workforce in the chemical sciences.

Dr. Keying Ding and her research team at Middle Tennessee State University will study new base-transition metal catalysts to address emerging challenges in catalytic reactions that utilize the “borrowing hydrogen” mechanistic pathway. A new family of bifunctional ligands that feature reactive pendant arms that potentially promote hydrogen transfer reactions via metal-ligand cooperativity, and that contain rigid ligand scaffolds to provide stability, will be synthesized and characterized. The catalytic activities of the base transition-metal complexes will be determined with a focus on (i) establishing an in-depth understanding of the BH catalytic process, (ii) eliminating the dependence on the use of excess strong base in the BH reactions, and (iii) improving the product selectivity. New concepts and insights on the use of earth-abundant metals in place of precious transition metals for BH and related transformations are expected to arise from these studies to help guide the development of future catalysts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview
This project, funded by the National Science Foundation, aimed to advance the field of catalysis by rethinking the concept of "borrowing hydrogen" (BH) through innovative ligand design, new catalytic reactions, and mechanistic studies. The project focused on developing sustainable and efficient catalytic systems using first-row transition metals (iron, cobalt, and manganese) to enable greener chemical transformations. Over the course of the award, significant progress was made in synthesizing novel ligands, optimizing catalytic processes, and training the next generation of scientists.

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit of this project lies in the development of new pincer ligands and their corresponding metal complexes, which have demonstrated remarkable catalytic activity in borrowing hydrogen processes. Key achievements include:

  1. Ligand Design and Synthesis: Novel pincer ligands such as iPrPPPBF, iPrPPPOH, PhPNHN, and iPrPPPCHPyMe were designed and synthesized. These ligands were tailored to stabilize metal centers and enhance catalytic performance in BH reactions.
  2. Catalytic Discoveries:
    • Cobalt-Catalyzed Dehydrogenative Coupling of Primary Alcohols to Esters: The cobalt complex (iPrPPPBF)CoCl₂ was shown to efficiently catalyze the dehydrogenative coupling of primary alcohols to esters. This reaction was optimized to achieve high yields (up to 99%) with minimal base loading (3.75 mol% KOtBu). The optimal conditions involved heating the reaction mixture in benzene at 125°C for 24 hours. This process provides a sustainable route to ester synthesis, which is important for the production of fragrances, flavors, and polymers.
    • Manganese-Catalyzed Dehydrogenative Coupling of Alcohols and Amines to Secondary Amines: The manganese complex (iPrPPPBF)MnBr(CO)₂ demonstrated excellent activity in the dehydrogenative coupling of alcohols and amines to form secondary amines. This reaction was optimized to achieve high yields (up to 94%) with minimal base loading (35 mol% KOtBu).
    • Cobalt-Catalyzed Dehydrogenative Coupling of Alcohols and Amines to Secondary Amines: The cobalt complex (iPrPPPOH)CoCl₂ demonstrated excellent activity in the dehydrogenative coupling of primary alcohols and anilines to form secondary amines. This reaction was optimized to achieve high yields (up to 99%) with reduced base loading (25 mol% KOtBu), making it a more sustainable alternative to traditional methods.
    • Cobalt-Catalyzed β-Methylation of Secondary Alcohols: A sustainable method for the β-methylation of secondary alcohols using methanol was developed. The cobalt complex (iPrPPPOH)CoCl₂ catalyzed this reaction, achieving good to excellent yields with minimal base loading (3.75 mol% KOtBu). This method offers a greener alternative to traditional multi-step methylation processes, which often involve toxic reagents and generate hazardous byproducts.
  3. Utilization of Earth-Abundant Metals for Amine/Alcohol Couplings with Reduced Base Additives: A significant breakthrough in this project was the discovery of earth-abundant metal catalysts (cobalt and manganese) for the dehydrogenative coupling of amines and alcohols, which significantly reduced the need for base additives. Traditionally, these reactions required a large excess of base, which is both costly and environmentally unfriendly. By optimizing the ligand design and reaction conditions, we were able to achieve high yields of secondary amines using only 25-35 mol% of base, a substantial reduction compared to previous systems. This advancement not only makes the process more sustainable but also more economically viable for industrial applications.

 Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project are significant and multifaceted:

  1. Sustainability: The catalytic systems developed during this project reduce reliance on toxic reagents, excess base loadings, minimize waste, and lower energy consumption, contributing to the advancement of green chemistry.
  2. Education and Training: The project provided extensive research training for four Master's students and five undergraduate students. These students gained hands-on experience in synthetic chemistry, advanced characterization techniques (e.g., X-ray crystallography, NMR spectroscopy, GC chromatography), and scientific communications.
  3. Scientific Dissemination: Research findings were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and theses. Notably, one paper was published in Tetrahedron (2021), and additional manuscripts are in preparation. Students presented their work at conferences such as Scholars Week, enhancing their professional development and visibility in the scientific community.

 Conclusion

This project has significantly advanced the field of borrowing hydrogen catalysis, demonstrating the potential of first-row transition metals to enable sustainable and efficient chemical transformations. The outcomes of this work have broad implications for green chemistry, pharmaceutical synthesis, and materials science. We are grateful to the National Science Foundation for their support and look forward to building on these findings in future research.

 


Last Modified: 02/20/2025
Modified by: Keying Ding

Cobalt-Catalyzed       -Methylation of Secondary Alcohols: A sustainable method for the       -methylation of secondary alcohols using methanol was developed. The       cobalt complex (iPrPPPOH)CoCl₂ catalyzed this reaction, achieving       good to excellent yields with minimal base loading (3.75 mol% KOtBu). By optimizing the ligand design and reaction conditions, we were able to achieve high yields of secondary amines using only 25-35 mol% of base, a substantial reduction compared to previous systems. This advancement not only makes the process more sustainable but also more economically viable for industrial applications.
 


Broader Impacts


The broader impacts of this project are significant and multifaceted:

Sustainability: The catalytic systems developed during this project reduce reliance on      toxic reagents, excess base loadings, minimize waste, and lower energy      consumption, contributing to the advancement of green chemistry.
Education      and Training: The project provided extensive research training for      four Master's students and five undergraduate students. This project has significantly advanced the field of borrowing hydrogen catalysis, demonstrating the potential of first-row transition metals to enable sustainable and efficient chemical transformations. The outcomes of this work have broad implications for green chemistry, pharmaceutical synthesis, and materials science. We are grateful to the National Science Foundation for their support and look forward to building on these findings in future research.
